awd_titl_txt: BIOME-A Bio-Robotic Infrastructure for Oceanic Microbial Ecology
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI's request funding to develop BIOME, a Bio-Robotic Infrastructure for Oceanic Microbial Ecology. Coastal ecosystems are central to global biogeochemical cycles despite their relatively small size; therefore, biological oceanography has focused on understanding microbial bloom dynamics on continental shelves. Unfortunately, our concepts of how a diverse bacterial community transitions between seasons remain incomplete because of our inability to sample on the appropriate time and spaces scales to resolve the processes influencing the microbiota. In order to address this limitation, we are proposing a build a biological sampler compatible with the Slocum Glider. What is missing is a component capable of collecting and returning intact biomass to the laboratory for molecular ecology studies to delineate the mechanisms driving bacterial evolution in the sea. this project will provide a platform to define the metabolic and genomic properties and mechanisms responsible for microbial growth, adaptation, and survival in the oceanic environment. The BIOME research will address fundamental questions in marine ecology and elucidate the mechanisms supporting the diversity of microorganisms in the ocean.

Broader Impacts:  

The potential broad impacts of this proposal are greater than average because the device being designed has potential to be deployed widely if it is successful and would lead to more accurate models of ocean microbial community structure and activity. The PIs propose to develop a K-12 lesson plan about bacteria in the Mid-Atlantic Bight with the help of an education outreach specialist associated with the Mid Atlantic Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence, and have included this aspect of the project in the budget. There is a plan for disseminating the lessons to K-12 teachers through a variety of on-line and summer teacher training programs, to the public through lectures at local library, and to kids through the Rutgers 4-H after school programs. The PIs also intend (though don't lay out any specific plan) to include underrepresented ethnic groups in summer research through the RISE @ Rutgers program.

BIOME--A Bio-Robotic Infrastructure for Oceanic Microbial Ecology  

Public Outcome Report

NSF 1131022-Oct., 2011-Sept., 2015 

Lee J. Kerkhof- PI

Department for Marine and Coastal Sciences, Rutgers University

phone: (848) 932-3419     email: lkerkhof@rutgers.edu

Jingang Yi -co-PI 

Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers University

phone: (848) 445-3282    email: jgyi@rutgers.edu

 

The overall goal of the proposed work was to design and build a bio-robotic sampling device capable of retrieving intact, biological materials from the ocean.  Our original research plan included prototype construction in year 1 of the project, sampler/system optimization in year 2, and field deployment in year 3.  During the project our efforts to develop and publish a low power-room temperature preservation method, called BioDry (1) for biological molecules were successful.   Additionally, we designed a portable BioDry “field unit", constructed from off-the-shelf materials and a battery-operated pumping system, which also displayed high levels of microbial community preservation over 30 days (Fig 1).  Unfortunately, we were unable to meet many of these objectives of the project due to the inability of the various robotic prototypes we developed to adequately preserve nucleic acid samples.  However, it is hoped our publication will greatly assist other members of the ocean sciences community to develop robotic infrastructure to sample and preserve biomolecules for oceanic samples.  At this stage, a redesign of our robotic sampler is in order.

In addition to the sampler, the project funds supported a graduate student determining the metabolic capability of microbes in a NJ salt marsh (2) and across the North Atlantic from Trinidad/Tobego to the Grand Banks (3). The results indicate both thaumarchaea and bacteria compete for organic compounds in the deep sea.  Finally, some funding was also used to develop an approach to rapidly sequence bacterial ribosomal operons within natural samples with the Oxford Nanopore (ONT) MinIon.  The MinIOn is a 3rd generation system for direct sequencing of individual DNA molecules that fits in the palm of your hand (see Google Images). The MinIOn MK1 connects to a laptop computer and collects/analyzes DNA sequence data in real-time.  Our method could detect over 1000 different microbes within natural samples and represents a cost-effective way to characterize microbial communities, requiring little to no bioinformatics training.  The details of this study are also being readied for publication (4).  Because the MinIon is small, portable, and runs on a laptop, the possibility of microbiome characterization in the field or on robotic platforms becomes realistic.  

The project supported a post-doctoral researcher in the Inst. of Marine and Coastal Sciences, a masters level engineering student in the Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, and an undergraduate student majoring in Biotechnology during summers. This interdisciplinary training for all participants fostered both career development and professional placement.  In addition, the project also partially supported a graduate student in Oceanography who graduated in June of 2015.  

Open Access Scientific papers.

1)  Tuorto SJ, Brown CM, Bidle KD, McGuinness LR, Kerkhof LJ (2015) BioDry: An Inexpensive, Low-Power Method to Preserve Aquatic Microbial Biomass at Room Temperature. PLoS ONE 10(12): e0144686. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0144686 

2)  Seyler LM, McGuinness LR, and Kerkhof LJ.  2014.  Crenarchaeal heterotrophy in salt marsh sediments. The ISME Journal 8: 1534–1543; doi:10.1038/ismej.2014.15 

 

 Near Submission.

3)  Seyler LM, McGuinness LR, Gilbert JA,Biddle JF, Gong D, Kerkhof LJ.  2016.  Discerning marine archaeal mixotrophy and heterotrophy in the deep North Atlantic. 

 4)  Kerkhof LJ, Dillon KP and McGuinness LR.  2016.   Bacterial microbiome profiling by MinIon sequencing of ribosomal operons.
